description: Unit 1.20 looks over the square towards the Bargehouse building from the first floor walkway of OXO Tower Wharf, immediately at the top of the steps; multi-purpose as showroom, workspace and teaching space.

events.name: LEATHER WORKSHOP
events.notes: Learn to make a beautiful Italian veg. tanned leather card case and key fob in this 2.5 hour class. The price is £75 and the link to book is here: https://www.carreducker.com/shop/shoemaking-classes/leathercraft-classes/leather-craft-open-house-london/

events.name: FAMILY FOB WORKSHOP
events.notes: Have fun together making and personalising three Italian veg. tanned leather fobs - stylish key fobs, bag pulls or name tags - in this 2-hour class. The price is £35 and the link to book is here: https://www.carreducker.com/shop/shoemaking-classes/leathercraft-classes/discover-making-open-house-london-family-fob-workshop/

events.name: General access
events.notes: Studio 50 onlyVisitors can arrive at any time during the opening hours.There may be queues at busy times.

factsheet.heading: History
paragraphs: Oxo Tower Wharf is just one part of the 13 acres owned and developed (mostly as housing) by Coin Street.
Today, it is a popular destination with diners, drinkers and shoppers and is home to 78 flats in a cooperative, low-rent housing scheme run by Coin Street.

factsheet.heading: Development
paragraphs: OXO Tower Wharf was originally built at the end of the 19th century as a power station for Royal Mail, but was bought by the Liebig Extract of Meat Company, makers of Oxo stock in the early 1900s. They redeveloped the wharf and added the distinctive tower as a landmark in 1929.

Apparently an original application to have OXO spelt out on the tower as an illuminated sign was turned down, so instead the three letters were incorporated into the structure of the building as an architectural feature.
